statement.text: Permissive hypotension is a deliberate resuscitation strategy in ruptured aortic aneurysm and other hemorrhagic emergencies that accepts lower-than-normal blood pressure targets to minimize ongoing hemorrhage while maintaining critical end-organ perfusion. By targeting systolic blood pressure of 70-90 mmHg in an awake, responsive patient, this approach preserves the hemostatic clot, avoids dilutional coagulopathy from crystalloid overload, and prevents 'popping the clot' that has tamponaded the rupture site. The strategy is maintained only until aortic control is achieved, after which normal resuscitation targets apply.
statement.formal: Permissive Hypotension: Target SBP 70-90 mmHg in awake patient, minimize crystalloid, use blood products (1:1:1 ratio), avoid vasopressors. Continue until aortic clamp applied, then resuscitate to normal goals.

explanation.intuition: Think of a dam with a crack that's been temporarily plugged by debris. If you increase the water pressure behind the dam, you'll blow out the plug and cause catastrophic flooding. Similarly, in a ruptured aorta, the body has formed a clot that's temporarily stopping the bleeding. Raising blood pressure with aggressive fluid resuscitation is like raising the water level behind the dam - it can blow out the clot and cause uncontrollable hemorrhage.
explanation.key_insight: The paradigm shift is recognizing that 'normal' blood pressure is harmful in the pre-operative phase of ruptured AAA. Aggressive resuscitation to normalize blood pressure is counterproductive because: (1) higher pressure increases transmural stress across the rupture site, (2) crystalloid dilutes clotting factors and causes coagulopathy, and (3) disrupting the retroperitoneal tamponade converts contained to free rupture.
explanation.technical_details: Permissive hypotension is a component of damage control resuscitation (DCR), which also includes minimizing crystalloid, early blood product administration (1:1:1 ratio of PRBCs:FFP:platelets), preventing hypothermia, and correcting acidosis. The target SBP of 70-90 mmHg maintains adequate coronary and cerebral perfusion in most patients while minimizing hydrostatic pressure on the rupture site. Clinical endpoints include mental status (must remain awake and responsive), urine output (some is acceptable, not targeting normal), and lactate (trending, not targeting normal). Vasopressors are generally avoided pre-operatively because they increase afterload and transmural pressure on the rupture.

hemostatic_clot_preservation.mechanism: Lower transmural pressure reduces force on clot
hemostatic_clot_preservation.evidence: Observational data suggest improved survival with restrictive resuscitation

prevention_coagulopathy.crystalloid_harm: Dilutes clotting factors, causes hypothermia, worsens acidosis
prevention_coagulopathy.blood_product_benefit: Provides clotting factors, oxygen-carrying capacity, volume without dilution

retroperitoneal_tamponade.risk_of_loss: Hypertension can disrupt tamponade → free rupture

resuscitation_endpoints: Urine output (some production, not targeting normal)

fluid_restriction.crystalloid: Minimize - only small boluses if truly hypotensive

vasopressors.pre_operative: Generally avoided (increases afterload on rupture site)
vasopressors.exception: Impending arrest, bridge to OR with REBOA

implementation.temperature_management: Prevent hypothermia - warm fluids, bear hugger

duration.end: When aortic clamp is applied (proximal control achieved)
duration.post_control: Resuscitate aggressively to normal goals once bleeding controlled

relative_contraindications: Severe coronary artery disease (may cause myocardial ischemia)
Prior stroke or significant carotid disease
absolute_contraindications: Isolated severe head injury (needs CPP maintenance)

supporting_evidence.observational: Multiple series show improved survival with restrictive resuscitation in rAAA
supporting_evidence.trauma_literature: PROPPR trial supports balanced resuscitation (1:1:1 ratio)
supporting_evidence.physiologic: Strong mechanistic rationale for reducing pressure on rupture site

outcome_improvement.mortality_reduction: Observational data suggest 15-20% relative reduction in mortality
outcome_improvement.mechanism: Prevents clot disruption, reduces blood loss, maintains coagulation

ideal_candidate.description: 65-year-old male, known 6cm AAA, acute back pain, SBP 85, alert and oriented
ideal_candidate.management: Maintain SBP 80-90, activate MTP, expedited CTA → rEVAR if suitable

borderline_case.description: Same patient but SBP 65, confused, cold extremities
borderline_case.management: Small volume resuscitation to restore mentation, consider REBOA, immediate OR

contraindicated_case.description: Patient with known LVEF 25%, active angina at rest
contraindicated_case.management: May need higher BP targets to maintain coronary perfusion - individualize

definition.@value: Resuscitation strategy accepting lower blood pressure targets (SBP 70-90 mmHg) to minimize ongoing hemorrhage and preserve hemostatic clot until aortic control is achieved

sources.citation: IMPROVE Trial Investigators. Endovascular or open repair strategy for ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm: 30 day outcomes from IMPROVE randomised trial. BMJ. 2014;348:f7661.
Dick F, et al. European guidelines on management of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2011;41(suppl 1):S1-S58.
Holcomb JB, et al. Transfusion of plasma, platelets, and red blood cells in a 1:1:1 vs a 1:1:2 ratio and mortality in patients with severe trauma (PROPPR). JAMA. 2015;313(5):471-82.

learning_objectives: Explain the physiologic rationale for permissive hypotension
Identify appropriate blood pressure targets in ruptured AAA
Recognize when permissive hypotension is contraindicated
Understand the timing of permissive hypotension (pre-clamp only)
Describe the role of adjuncts (TXA, calcium, fibrinogen)
clinical_pearls: A talking, oriented patient with SBP 80 is safer than one aggressively resuscitated to 120
Crystalloid is the enemy - use blood products from the start
Mental status is your most important endpoint - if they're awake, they're perfusing
Vasopressors increase afterload on the rupture site - avoid pre-operatively
Once the clamp is on, resuscitate aggressively to normal goals
Permissive hypotension is a bridge to definitive repair, not a destination
